The 4 dollar (USD) Coiled Hair Stella, which was struck in the U.S. but never released for circulation, brought an astonishing 2,574,000 dollars (USD) at auction by Bonhams in Los Angeles on... on.aol.com 
Coin collectors are searching for alternatives of raising cash from their coin collecting without selling their coin collection. An alternative would be to take a loan on the valuable coins in your collection. Your coins would need to be graded and certified by a major certification company to take a loan on your coins . Most lenders prefer PCGS or NGC grading companies while others would include ANACS . Since, you would be pledging your collateral as security for the loan credit isn't a factor in determining whether you can borrow the money. Photo by Louis J. Pinga 
A method for raising cash through a private offering would prove feasible so that your rare coins or gold coins can be certified and encapsulated. Important note make sure you follow the SEC Rule regulation D for limited offerings as well as the Blue Sky Securities laws in Rhode Island and any State you plan on making such an offering. You should seek legal advice before venturing into a Securities offering. Securities offerings which raise money for coin grading fees essentially you are raising equity capital from investors which self liquidates when the coins are sold. 
Some large coin auction companies or coin dealers may negotiate with coin collectors for the subsequent sale by auction or private treaty and provide upfront funds to certify and encapsulate your raw ungraded coins . Most likely in this case you would be agreeing to sell your coins through either private treaty or the auction method of marketing by this major auction company that specializes in numismatics . 
A trusted lender for rare coins is Edelmanâ€™s Coins in Jenkintown, PA. There are other lenders who provide acquisition loans to buy rare coins at major Auction houses.
